Public Information Requests

Government » Resources »
  • Resources
  • Elections
  • Government Transparency
  • Public Information Requests

Texas Government Code, Chapter 552, gives you the right to access government records; and an officer for public information and the officer’s agent may not ask why you want them. All government information is presumed to be available to the public. Certain exceptions may apply to the disclosure of the information. Governmental bodies shall promptly release requested information that is not confidential by law, either constitutional, statutory, or by judicial decision, or information for which an exception to disclosure has not been sought.

The City of Troy understands and supports the public's right to access the public records created and maintained by the City in the course of their normal business. It is the goal of the City to provide service in a transparent manner, which includes timely access to requested records in accordance with the Public Information Act (PIA). 

Public Information Act (English)

Public Information Act (Spanish)

 

What are Public Records?

“Public records” include any information that is collected, assembled, or maintained by or for a government entity. It includes information that is maintained in paper, tape, microfilm, video, electronic data held in a computer memory, as well as other mediums specified under law.

 

What is a public information request?

Is a request for public documents and records under Texas Public Information Act or, Govt. Code 552

 

How do I submit an Open Records Request?

The only legal requirement to submit a request is that it be in writing. 

A written request should: 

    • be very specific on the records being requested; 

    • please include mailing address, phone number, or other contact information to contact you regarding 

      your request. 

    • There is not a specific form required for submitting requests, but one is provided below for your 

       convenience. 

 

Requests may be submitted by any of the options below: 

  • By email
    Open Records Request
    Click on the link and describe in the email the information you are requesting from the City. 
    You may use any sheet of paper and send your request by fax, by mail or bring your request to our office 
  • Fax to:
    Fax #: 254.938.0440
    City Hall
    City Administrator’s Office
    RE: Open Records Request 
  • Mail to:
    City Administrator’s Office
    Attn: City Administrator
    PO Box 389
    Troy, Texas 76579
  • In Person:
    Come to the City Hall and submit your request to the City Administrator.
    City Of Troy - City Hall
    City Administrator’s Office
    201 E. Main Street
    Troy, Texas 76579

Citizens with additional questions please call our office at 254.938.2505

 

Inspect Records:

It is advisable for any person who wishes to inspect public records to complete a public information request so that the City can make sure the records are available. Advanced notice is required to inspect public records; the inspection of records is subject to a rule of reason and must be consistent with the efficient functioning of City offices. An appointment may have to be scheduled if the records are being used by City staff, if the records must be found and reviewed, when the requested records are stored off site or redaction of confidential information is necessary. In order to prevent records from being lost, damaged or destroyed during inspection, City staff may determine the location of, and may monitor the inspection. Public records are open to inspection during regular City office hours, except for City holidays. While there are charges for the duplication of records (photocopies, CDs, and DVDs) there is no charge to inspect or view records. 

 

What isn't considered a public record under the law?

Without a specific exception confirmed by the Texas Attorney General, all information is considered public. The City of Troy need not request an attorney general decision if it is redacting information pursuant to one of the five sections of the Public Information Act. The five sections are 552.024, 552.130, 552.136, 552.138 and 552.1175.

 

Could there be a charge for requested information?

Public Information Fee Schedule -Click on the link for the fee schedule.

 

Where can I get police/arrest records?

Troy Police Department keep arrest records and accident reports. Please contact the Troy Police Department for further information.

 

Where can I get court records?

The Troy Municipal Court of Record is responsible the adjudication of all Class "C" misdemeanor laws established by State Law and City Ordinance within the Territorial limits of the City of Troy. Please contact the Troy Municipal Court.

 

Tips for Successful Open Records Requests:

  • Good practice to clearly label your correspondence as a "Public Information Request" or  "Open Records Request".
  • Your request should be for documents or other information that are already in existence.
  • The City of Troy is not required
    • To answer questions
    • Perform legal research
    • Comply with a continuing request to supply information on a periodic basis that has information in the future.
